Description: Egyptian terracotta model palmette acroterion. The upper corner broken from a miniature altar, decorated on each side with a half-palmette. The altar was made in a multiple mould, probably of two pieces, but perhaps more. Traces of a matt red slip survive, inside and out and signs of burning within. Brown Nile silt with a light-brown core, abundant fine gold mica and some white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Similar palmette parallel (Fischer 1994, no.1217), from Hawara (Petrie 1889, pl.15, no.8; Petrie 1911, pl.15, no.6, Petrie Museum UC19387) and one from House K at Herakleopolis Magna, dated 3rd century AD (Petrie 1905, pl. 52a, no.167). Bailey dates this piece between the 2nd and 1st century BC (Bailey 2008, 84). Fischer, J. 1994, Griechisch-römische Terrakotten aus Ägypten. Die Sammlungen Sieglin und Schreiber. Dresden, Leipzig, Stuttgart, Tübingen. Tübingen, Wasmuth. Petrie, W. M. F. 1889, Hawara, Biahmu and Arsinoe. London. Petrie, W. M. F. 1905, Roman Ehnasya (Herakleopolis Magna) 1904. London. Petrie, W. M. F. 1911, Memphis, vol IV: Roman Portraits and Memphis. London.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3270)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (ME.7) (Phase 3)
